page.title: 13GIMINGHAM
page.content: The picturesque village of Gimingham lies in a valley on the banks of the Mun, a rivulet which empties into the sea at Mundesley a mile away. The church is set in an attractive group of trees quite near the large village pond. The pond is really the dam to supply power for the former water-mill which burnt down in 1979. The mill site and nearby barns have now been renovated and turned into domestic properties and the are other small estates in the village. "Gallows Hill" and the Pound for stray animals remind us of the village past.There is a mystry about the place. somewhere in the parish is a palace belonging to John of Gaunt, father of Henry 1V. The surrounding area is rolling farm- land, with three farms and two riding schools in the area.
